<green>Green</green>
<GREENSQL_DB_ABOUT>Database names coincide to the names of databases on the backend SQL server.[br]
A database should be coupled with a GreenSQL Router[br]
A number of databases can use the same GreenSQL Router.[br]
You can edit the permissions for each database to block actions such as changes to DB structure, execution of sensitive commands
</GREENSQL_DB_ABOUT>
<green_enable_dns_service_explain>If turned to [b]Green[/b] then you will active the DNS service on this server.[br]If you turn to [b]Red[/b], then you will disable the DNS service on this server</green_enable_dns_service_explain>
<greylist_intro>If turned to green, it implements the greylist filtering method.[br]
Grey listing works by assuming that, unlike legitimate MTA, spam engines will not retry sending their junk mail on a temporary error.[br]
The filter will always reject mail temporarily on a first attempt, then accept it after some time has elapsed.[br]
If spammers ever try to resend rejected messages, we can assume they will not stay idle between 
the two sends (if they do, the spam problem would just be solved).[br]
Odds are good that the spammer will send a mail to a honey pot address and get blacklisted in several real-time distributed black lists before the second attempt.
</greylist_intro>
<gre_route_explain>If set, it defines the Route to send the content back to the GRE tunnel.[br]
Example: 192.168.182.225/32
</gre_route_explain>
<group2>Gruppe</group2>
<groupe_type>Group type</groupe_type>
<groups2>Gruppen</groups2>
<groupsF>Gruppen</groupsF>
<groups_checking>Groups checking</groups_checking>
<groups_for_rules>Rules Group</groups_for_rules>
<groups_retreiver>Groups retreiver</groups_retreiver>
<groups_retreiver_explain>For statistics purpose and for specifics ACLs Artica need to retrieve only one group from an user.[br]
You can link multiple groups to an user trough Active Directory but Artica needs to retreive only one.[br]
By default, Artica use the first group found in the group list.[br]
You can define a regular expression if you need to retrieve a specific group.[br]
For example: [b]^INTERNET_[/b] will find the first group started by INTERNET_ keywords like ( INTERNET_FULL, INTERNET_MEDIUM...).[br]
Or you can choose an Active Directory attribute in the drop-down list that allows Artica to set it as group.
</groups_retreiver_explain>
<groups_retriever>Groups retriever</groups_retriever>
<groups_retriever_explain>For statistics purpose and for specifics ACLs Artica need to retrieve only one group from an user.[br]
Active Directory allows you to link multiple groups for an user but Artica needs to retrieve only one.[br]
By default, Artica use the first group found in the group list.[br]
You can define a regular expression if you need to retrieve a specific group.[br]
For example: [b]^INTERNET_[/b] will find the first group started by INTERNET_ keywords like ( INTERNET_FULL, INTERNET_MEDIUM...).[br]
Or you can choose an Active Directory attribute in the drop-down list that allows Artica to set it as group.
</groups_retriever_explain>
<GROUP_ATTRIBUTE>Group attribute</GROUP_ATTRIBUTE>
<group_explain_proxy_acls_type_0>an LDAP group is designed to store members stored into an LDAP server.[br]
Basically it use the local LDAP system.
</group_explain_proxy_acls_type_0>
<group_explain_proxy_acls_type_1>A virtual group is designed to store multiple items type such as IP Addresses, netmasks, members...</group_explain_proxy_acls_type_1>
<group_explain_proxy_acls_type_2>An Active Directory group is designed to only store Active Directory members from the linked Active Directory</group_explain_proxy_acls_type_2>
<group_explain_proxy_acls_type_3>Use the remote LDAP server defined in the global configuration</group_explain_proxy_acls_type_3>
<group_explain_proxy_acls_type_4>This group allows you to use an external Active Directory server and a dedicated Active Directory group.[br]
It is used when you use Artica as HotSpot and using Active Directory authentication to filter members according their Active Directory group
</group_explain_proxy_acls_type_4>
<group_explain_proxy_acls_type_5>Set here the name of the Organization Unit that stores your Active Directory users.[br]
Available value can be the organization name: [b]My_OU[/b].[br]The asterisk (*) indicates zero (0) or more characters: Bob* or *Johnson  or *John* or B*John
[br]
If there are organizations that have the same name then Artica will get users from all organizations.
</group_explain_proxy_acls_type_5>

bandwidth will be given to the container when it needs it.[br]
If the container does not need the bandwidth, it will be available for any other container to use.</Guaranteed_Rate_explain>

<haproxy_choose_service>Define the main settings of your new service and choose the service type:[br]
[b]HTTP/HTTPs Proxy Load-balancer[/b]: Designed to be an high availability service of Artica proxies[br] 
[b]Reverse Proxy[/b]: Designed to redirect/balance connections to HTTP/HTTPS Web services[br]
[b]TCP redirect[/b]: Designed to redirect/balance TCP connections to other servers.[br]
[b]SMTP redirect[/b]: Designed to redirect/balance SMTP connections to mail servers.[br]
</haproxy_choose_service>
<haproxy_local_interface_help>Set the source address for outgoing connections</haproxy_local_interface_help>
<HAPROXY_NOBACKENDS_DEFINED>The Load-balancing service is enabled but no backend has been defined on your load-balancing service.[br]
In this case, the Load-balancing service could not be started</HAPROXY_NOBACKENDS_DEFINED>
<haproxy_website_explain>Set here the website domain.[br]
Example: [b]www.company.com[/b] will strictly correspond www.company.com.[br]
if you want to catch the whole domain add a dot on before the domain.[br]
Example: [b].company.com[/b] will correspond to www.company.com,www1.company.com,www2.company.com.[br]
To define a default site, means all websites set [b]*[/b] star to the field.
</haproxy_website_explain>
<haproxy_weight_explain>This parameter is used to adjust the server's weight relative to other servers.[br]
All servers will receive a load proportional to their weight relative to the sum of all weights, so the higher the weight, the higher the load.[br]
The default weight is 1, and the maximal value is 256.[br]
It is recommended to start with values which can both grow and shrink, for instance between 10 and 100 to leave enough room above and below for later adjustments.
</haproxy_weight_explain>

<high_swap_value_exceed_explain>Ihr Server verwendet derzeit den Swap-Speicher, um Aufgaben zu bearbeiten. Das bedeutet, dass die Festplatte statt des Speichers verwendet wird.

Sie sollten den Arbeitsspeicher des Servers erh%C3%B6hen oder die Artica-Parameter untersuchen, um das Anhalten einiger Dienste zu erzwingen oder deren Speicherverbrauch zu reduzieren.</high_swap_value_exceed_explain>

<hostpot2_pattern_explain>Definieren Sie hier Firewall-Regeln, die unter 3 Bedingungen verwendet werden: global, wenn der Benutzer bekannt ist (angemeldet), wenn der Benutzer unbekannt ist (nicht angemeldet).[br]
Im Feld &quot;Muster&quot; k%C3%B6nnen Sie ein komplettes Netzwerk wie 192.168.0.0/16 oder eine einzelne IP-Adresse definieren.[br]
Verwenden Sie 0.0.0.0/0, um alles zu definieren.[br]
Wenn Sie keinen Port oder einen Port 0 angeben, bedeutet dies &quot;alle Ports&quot;.[br]
Wenn Sie einen Host oder einen Webserver angeben, wird Artica diesen aufl%C3%B6sen, bevor die Regel erstellt wird.</hostpot2_pattern_explain>

<hostpot_net>Hotspot network</hostpot_net>
<hostpot_pattern_explain>Give here the source network.[br]
It should be a global network - 192.168.1.0/24 - and IP address: 192.168.1.245 or a MAC address.[br]
You should choose if the source is "hotspoted". if not "hotspoted", then node will pass without need to login trough web authentication form.[br]
In this case, you should add an "uid" that will be added in proxy events in order to track connections.[br]
If the network is not whitelisted then the node have to login on the Web authentication page.[br]
if the restrict option is enabled the node will only have access to HTTP/HTTPS. Others services will be banned.
</hostpot_pattern_explain>

<htcp_port>HTCP port</htcp_port>
<htcp_port_explain>
[b]Hyper Text Caching Protocol[/b][br]
This is a UDP based fetch-response protocol used to discover if a sibling peer has an object from the same URL already stored.[br]
see RFC 2756 for details on this protocol.[br]
This protocol sends whole HTTP headers to the peer for response decision making.[br]
It should be preferred over ICP selection wherever possible, but can cause a larger background traffic overhead.[br]+++
The port number where Squid sends and receives HTCP queries to and from neighbor caches.[br]
To turn it on you want to set it to [b]4827[/b].[br]By default it is set to "0" (disabled).</htcp_port_explain>

<http_compression>HTTP compression</http_compression>
<http_compression_explain>Mit der HTTP-Komprimierung k%C3%B6nnen Sie HTTP-Inhalte im gzip-Format komprimieren.
Alle Browser unterst%C3%BCtzen das gzip-Format und sind in der Lage, Inhalte zu dekomprimieren (unter Verwendung des [b]Accept-Encoding gzip, deflate[/b] HTTP-Headers).
Es wurde entwickelt, um Bandbreite zu sparen und Inhalte von 40 bis 95 % zu komprimieren[br].
In den meisten F%C3%A4llen wird die GZIP-Komprimierung auf Webservern ausgef%C3%BChrt, aber viele Webserver haben die HTTP-Komprimierungsfunktion nicht aktiviert.[br]
Diese Funktion ist interessant, wenn sich Ihr Proxy in der Hauptniederlassung befindet und Browser oder entfernte Proxys bedient, die sich au%C3%9Ferhalb Ihrer lokalen Infrastruktur befinden[br].
Die Verwendung der HTTP-Komprimierung innerhalb eines LANs war nicht sinnvoll...</http_compression_explain>

<hugespages_explain>
This is a feature which allows processes to use large paging sizes, 
called as hugetlb pages.[br]It will be used to gain good performance in high performance computing systems.[br]
Hugetlb behavior is similar to that of bigpages, the pages are backed by large TLB entries, 
are not pageable, and are preallocated, which means that once you allocate X megabytes of hugetlb pages,
that amount of physical memory can be used only through hugetlbfs. 
</hugespages_explain>

<HYPERCACHE_STOREID>HyperCache Dedup</HYPERCACHE_STOREID>
<HYPERCACHE_STOREID_EXPLAIN>
Hypercache Dedup feature will increase the % HIT ratio with your Internet regarding web video, music, images and 
library files that were already viewed by users.[br]
Next time if a same object is requested again, the Hypercache dedup feature will retrieve it from the cache system 
without having to redownload it again.[br]
This significantly decreases the time access to the selected object, it also improves your Internet performances and saves your bandwidth for other users.
</HYPERCACHE_STOREID_EXPLAIN>

<IGNORE>Ignore</IGNORE>
<ignore-auth>
Proxy will be able to cache the authorization requests.[br]
Using this option may be really risky
</ignore-auth>
<ignore-must-revalidate>
The HTTP header [b]Cache-Control: must-revalidate[/b]
means that the response must be revalidated with the originating web server before it's used again.[br]
if set, it will enforce proxy to ignore this header.
</ignore-must-revalidate>
<ignore-no-store>
The HTTP header [b]Cache-Control: no-store[/b] is used to tell clients that they are not allowed 
to store the data being transmitted.[br] If set, Proxy will simply ignore this HTTP header 
and will cache the response if it's cacheable.
</ignore-no-store>
<ignore-private>
Private information or sensitive data generally carries an HTTP header known as [b]Cache-Control: private[/b] 
so that intermediate servers don't cache the responses.[br]
However, this option can be used to ignore this header.
</ignore-private>
<ignore-reload>
Simply ignore the [b]no-cache[/b] or [b]reload[/b] directives present in the HTTP headers
</ignore-reload>
<IgnoreICMPbroadcastrequests>Ignore ICMP broadcast requests</IgnoreICMPbroadcastrequests>

<incompatible_bigdata_engine>Incompatible BigData engine version.</incompatible_bigdata_engine>
<incompatible_bigdata_engine_explain1>During tests we have encountered issues on the 0.8x BigData engine version.[br]
Click here to fix it and to know why</incompatible_bigdata_engine_explain1>
<incompatible_bigdata_engine_explain2>If you see this message, it seems you have installed our next Artica version [b]2.0 RC1 or 2.0 RC2[/b].[br]
During our latest tests and with our customers, we have encountered some fatal issues on the InfluxDB engine version 0.8x.[br]
This issue make the listen port unavailable and cannot be reopen after several retsarts.[br]
To fix this major issue, you need to reconstruct a freshed database but you loose datas.[br]
In order to fix this issue you need to upgrade the engine to the 0.9x version.[br]
This main engine version will be included in our next official Artica [b]Release[/b] 
This upgrade will re-create a new freshed database. This means datas will be removed.[br]
To upgrade, just click on the upgrade button.
</incompatible_bigdata_engine_explain2>

<indexes>Indexes</indexes>
<indexes_size>Indexes size</indexes_size>
<IndexIgnore_explain>
When your website visitor navigates to a directory or folder where you do 
not have an index file (index.htm, index.html, index.php, etc.), the browser displays something.[br]
What gets displayed depends on your configuration.[br]
The browser can display some error page, nothing, or it can also list all or some of the files included in that directory.[br]
This section allows you to exclude certain files or even everything from so-called directory listing or directory browsing.[br]
It adds to the list of files to hide when listing a directory.[br]
In other words, this section is often used to prevent unauthorized directory browsing or access to files.
</IndexIgnore_explain>
<IndexIgnore_howtoadd>Give the pattern: readme.txt hide the file
*.txt hide all txt files.
*logs hide all files and/or directories name with logs.
</IndexIgnore_howtoadd>
<index_in_attachments>Indexing attachments</index_in_attachments>

<influx_to_release_explain>The InfluxDB (BigData engine) is now turned to an official release.[br]
This new version fix many bugs and improve dramatically performances.[br]
There are so many changes between your current database engine and the new released engine.[br]
In this case you must upgrade your database engine but you [b]will loose all saved statistics.[br]
Artica must destroy your old database, old backups in order to upgrade to start a new freshed database.[br]
You can recover old datas by ask to artica to inject requests saved into your proxy logs.[br]
See the link bellow in order to see how to import events from your proxy logs.
</influx_to_release_explain>

<init_script_firewall_explain>Dieses Skript wird f%C3%BCr die Anwendung von Firewall-Regeln verwendet.

Bevor Sie die Regeln anwenden, k%C3%B6nnen Sie sie analysieren, um zu sehen, ob Sie etwas falsch sehen.
Wenn Sie mit dieser Konfiguration einverstanden sind, klicken Sie auf &quot;Firewall-Regeln anwenden&quot;, um Ihre %C3%84nderungen vorzunehmen.</init_script_firewall_explain>

It is executed when you apply the configuration or when the server is started or rebooted.[br]

</init_script_net_explain>
<injecting>Injecting</injecting>
<injecting_data>Injecting data</injecting_data>
<INNODB_FILE_PER_TABLE_ASK>Derzeit ist die MySQL-Engine so eingestellt, dass sie Indizes in einer einzigen Datei speichert.
Alles in einer einzigen gro%C3%9Fen Datei zu speichern bedeutet, dass alle Tabellen und Indizes aus allen Schemata in dieser Datei &quot;vermischt&quot; werden[br].
Wir empfehlen, diesen Parameter namens innodb_file_per_table auf eine .ibd-Datei aufzuteilen, die f%C3%BCr jede Tabelle erstellt wird, anstatt eine gro%C3%9Fe ibdata-Datei f%C3%BCr alle Daten zu verwenden.[br]
Eine Datei pro Tabelle bietet mehr Flexibilit%C3%A4t, um Tabellen auf verschiedene Dateisystempartitionen zu verschieben und so die Leistung zu verbessern.[br]
In diesem Fall:[br]
[br]Tablespace wird nicht zwischen verschiedenen Tabellen und schon gar nicht zwischen verschiedenen Schemata geteilt.[br]
Jede Datei wird als ein eigener Tablespace betrachtet.[br]
Der Tablespace verkleinert sich nie.[br]
Es ist m%C3%B6glich, pro Tablespace Platz zur%C3%BCckzugewinnen.[br]
[br]

[b]Was ist zu tun?[/b][br]
[br]1) Sie k%C3%B6nnen [b]die aktuellen Einstellungen beibehalten[/b] und diese Meldung verschwindet.[br]
In diesem Fall klicken Sie auf die Schaltfl%C3%A4che &quot;Ich verstehe, fahren Sie trotzdem fort&quot;.[br]
[br]2) Sie k%C3%B6nnen auf InnoDB-Datei pro Tabelle umschalten, aber die Wahl dieser Option wird Ihren Server w%C3%A4hrend der Konvertierungsprozedur besch%C3%A4ftigen.[br]Die von Artica durchgef%C3%BChrte Prozedur wird sein:[br]
Dumpen Sie alle MySQL-Tabellen in ein lokales Verzeichnis (Sie ben%C3%B6tigen mindestens %free freie Gr%C3%B6%C3%9Fe).[br]
Entfernen Sie %tablesnum auf Ihrem MySQL-Server.[br]
Stoppen Sie die MySQL-Server-Engine.[br]
Starten Sie die MySQL-Server-Engine.[br]
Importieren Sie %tablesnum auf Ihrem MySQL-Server.
[br]
Wenn dieser Server gerade in Gebrauch ist und Sie diesen Vorgang nicht durchf%C3%BChren k%C3%B6nnen,
lesen Sie den Link unten, um zu erfahren, wie Sie diesen Vorgang sp%C3%A4ter durchf%C3%BChren k%C3%B6nnen, und klicken Sie auf die Schaltfl%C3%A4che &quot;Ich verstehe, fahren Sie trotzdem fort&quot;.</INNODB_FILE_PER_TABLE_ASK>

<integrated_antivirus>Integrated Antivirus</integrated_antivirus>
<integrated_antivirus_explain>Integrated Antivirus act as an Antivirus plugin ( using eCAP library ), difference is the proxy not sends content to a ClamAV engine service, the Antivirus analysis is a part of the Proxy process.[br]
This reduce used resources by an additional service but increase memory used by the proxy itself.[br]
With this plugin, the Antivirus send directly an [b]Access Denied[/b] to the proxy, in this case no statistics and information are sent to the system.

<IT_charter_explain>Die Funktion Technology Charter erm%C3%B6glicht es dem Proxy-Dienst, Anfragen auf eine interne Webseite umzuleiten, die die Mitglieder zwingt, die Unternehmensrichtlinien zu lesen, bevor sie auf das Internet zugreifen.
Diese Funktion zeigt die Seite mit den Unternehmensrichtlinien nur einmal an, wenn der Benutzer die Benutzervereinbarung korrekt akzeptiert hat.
Jede Benutzervereinbarung wird protokolliert, um sicherzustellen, dass die Richtlinie gelesen wurde.
Sie k%C3%B6nnen mehrere Chartas erstellen.[br]Wenn ein Benutzer eine Richtlinienvereinbarung erfolgreich gelesen hat, sollte er zur n%C3%A4chsten Richtlinienvereinbarung weitergeleitet werden.</IT_charter_explain>
<IT_charter_explain2>[b]Notice[/b]The redirection is only made if the user is connected to an HTTP website.[br]
SSL protocol cannot be broken and redirected.[br]For example, the https://www.google.com will be not redirected but http://www.google.com will be redirected to the IT Chart</IT_charter_explain2>

<kernelnetworkoptimization>Kernel-Netzwerkoptimierung</kernelnetworkoptimization>
<KernelSendRedirects>Send out ICMP redirects to other hosts</KernelSendRedirects>
<KernelSendRedirects_explain>This option tells the Linux kernel to send out ICMP redirects to other hosts.[br]
This should only be turned on, if the computer acts as a router of some sort.[br]
The ICMP redirects are mainly sent out to hosts, 
if we for example know that the other router/host should instead contact another server on their same subnet as the one we are receiving the packets on.
The send_redirects variable takes a boolean value and is per default turned on.[br]
It can take the values 0 (off) and 1 (on).[br]
In most cases where the computer is not running as a router of some kind, we could safely turn it off.
</KernelSendRedirects_explain>

<ligghtpd_perf_howto>Basically, this Web interface use lighttpd Web server engine to provide Web management interface.[br]
Artica use 2 Web engine:[br]
The first is the Web engine that provides administration Web pages.[br]
The second is the framework that run in root and designed to listen orders from the Web interface on the loopback interface.[br]
According your server performance, you can increase or decrease the memory consumption of the Web engine.[br]
In this section, you can see the memory used and the process number used by the Web engine.
</ligghtpd_perf_howto>

<lists>Lists</lists>
<list_rsync>This parameter determines whether this module is listed when the client asks for a listing 
of available modules.[br]
In addition, if this is disabled, the daemon will pretend the module does not exist 
when a client denied by "hosts allow" or "hosts deny" attempts to access it.[br]
Realize that if "reverse lookup" is disabled globally but enabled for the module, 
the resulting reverse lookup to a potentially client-controlled DNS server may still 
reveal to the client that it hit an existing module.[br]
The default is for modules to be listable.</list_rsync>

<locales>Locales</locales>
<LOCALES_EXPLAIN>
A locale is a set of parameters that defines the user's language, 
region and any special variant preferences that the user wants to see in their user interface.[br]
Usually a locale identifier consists of at least a language identifier and a region identifier.[br]
These settings usually include the following display (output) format settings:[br]
Number format setting[br]
Character classification, case conversion settings[br]
Date-time format setting[br]
String collation setting[br]
Currency format setting[br]
Paper size setting[br]
other minor settings ...[br]
</LOCALES_EXPLAIN>

<LOG>log</LOG>
<log2>Event</log2>
<LogFileDaemonMaxEvents_explain>Artica Logger is a process that able to receive events directly from the Proxy service.[br]
In order to reduce I/O disk it keep events in memory and write then to disk after x requests saved in memory.[br]
In all cases, the logger process will write events file each minute.[br]
This parameter will define how many requests the logger will keep event during 1 minute.
</LogFileDaemonMaxEvents_explain>
<logfile_detect_categories>If turned to green the process will cheks to the category service to detect the correct category.[br]
This allows you to get categories in the realtime viewer but should stress the system according Category service will parse the full categories database</logfile_detect_categories>
<logfile_direct_to_mysql_explain>If turned to green, the Artica Logger Daemon will insert all Proxy requests to the MySQL service ( in memory mode).[br]
This behavior allows you to get events in realtime.[br]
According the number of requests, this behavior should stress the MySQL service.[br]
If Turned to red then the Artica Logger Daemon will save requests into the disk instead insert them into MySQL.[br]
A background task will be in charge to parse all logs and insert them into MySQL tables.[br]
In this case a stressed Proxy will have not impact to the MySQL service but events should be displayed few times after.
</logfile_direct_to_mysql_explain>
<logged_as>Logged as</logged_as>
<logged_in_as>Logged in as</logged_in_as>
<logging_childs_connections>Log childs connections</logging_childs_connections>
<logging_childs_connections2>Log connections to a different log file</logging_childs_connections2>
<logging_childs_connections_explain>If turn to green, connections from Proxy childs will be logged and added to the local statistics</logging_childs_connections_explain>
<logging_childs_connections_explain2>If green the proxy service will write requests to a dedicated events file.[br]
This dedicated events file will be not added to Artica statistics but allows you to monitor connections from backend proxys</logging_childs_connections_explain2>
<logging_is_on_emergency>Logging is on emergency</logging_is_on_emergency>
<logging_is_on_emergency_explain>The proxy logging feature is on emergency mode, this means no events are saved and no statistics are generated</logging_is_on_emergency_explain>

In diesem Fall muss der HotSpot eine Umleitung zu einer [b]HTTP[/b] (nicht https) URI durchf%C3%BChren, um die Sitzung wiederherzustellen.
Wir nennen das eine verlorene Seite...[br]
Wenn ein Gastkonto diese verlorene Landing Page erreicht, wird dies die endg%C3%BCltige URL nach einer erfolgreichen Anmeldung sein, wenn keine Landing Page angegeben wurde.</lost_landing_page_explain>

<map_untrusted_to_domain>Map untrusted to domain</map_untrusted_to_domain>
<map_untrusted_to_domain_explain>Wenn dieser Server fr%C3%BCher ein Dom%C3%A4nenmitglied war und ein Client eine Verbindung mit einem
nicht vertrauensw%C3%BCrdigen Dom%C3%A4nennamen, wie z. B. BOGUSuser, verbindet, hat der Server die nicht vertrauensw%C3%BCrdige Dom%C3%A4ne auf die prim%C3%A4re Dom%C3%A4ne umgestellt
Der Server ordnete die nicht vertrauensw%C3%BCrdige Dom%C3%A4ne der prim%C3%A4ren Dom%C3%A4ne zu, in der der Server Mitglied war, und versuchte, sich mit diesem DOMAINBenutzernamen zu authentifizieren.
Dies unterscheidet sich von dem Verhalten eines Windows-Mitgliedsservers.
Jetzt ersetzt der Server den BOGUS-Namen durch seinen SAM-Namen.[br]
In dem Fall, in dem der Server als PDC fungiert, ist dies DOMAINuser.[br]
Wenn der Server als Dom%C3%A4nenmitgliedsserver fungiert, ist dies WORKSTATIONuser.[br]
Der Server geht also nie davon aus, dass ein eingehender Benutzername, der nicht mit derselben prim%C3%A4ren Dom%C3%A4ne qualifiziert ist
nicht mit der gleichen prim%C3%A4ren Dom%C3%A4ne qualifiziert ist, zur prim%C3%A4ren Dom%C3%A4ne des Servers geh%C3%B6rt.
W%C3%A4hrend dieses Verhalten mit Windows %C3%BCbereinstimmt, kann es einige Arbeitsabl%C3%A4ufe unterbrechen, die davon abh%C3%A4ngen
die darauf angewiesen sind, dass der Server gef%C3%A4lschte Namen immer zur %C3%9Cberpr%C3%BCfung an den DC weiterleitet.
Parameter &quot;map untrusted to domain&quot; kann [b]aktiviert[/b] werden, um zum alten Verhalten zur%C3%BCckzukehren.</map_untrusted_to_domain_explain>

<mark_section>Section for MARK TCP paquets</mark_section>
<mark_section_explain>All fields above are active only if you have enabled the [b]{MARK_ITEM}[/b] option</mark_section_explain>
<masquerade_whatis>IP Masquerade, also called IPMASQ or MASQ, allows one or more computers in a network without assigned IP addresses to communicate with the Internet using the Artica server's assigned IP address.[br]
The IPMASQ server acts as a gateway, and the other devices are invisible behind it, so to other machines on the Internet the outgoing traffic appears to be coming from the IPMASQ server and not the internal PCs.
</masquerade_whatis>
<masquerading>Masquerading</masquerading>
<masquerading_explain>Masquerading allows you to set up the routeur that connects your local network to the remote network.
Your local network will not be visible and the hosts appear as a single address on the target network.</masquerading_explain>
<masquerading_invert>Opposite masquerading</masquerading_invert>

<max_heap_table_size_text>This variable sets the maximum size to which user-created MEMORY tables are permitted to grow.[br]
The value of the variable is used to calculate MEMORY table MAX_ROWS values.[br]
Setting this variable has no effect on any existing MEMORY table, unless the table is re-created with a statement such as 
CREATE TABLE or altered with ALTER TABLE or TRUNCATE TABLE.[br]
A server restart also sets the maximum size of existing MEMORY tables to the global max_heap_table_size value.</max_heap_table_size_text>

<max_successive_pkts_lost>MAX aufeinanderfolgende Pakete verloren</max_successive_pkts_lost>
<max_swap_rate>MAX SWAP rate</max_swap_rate>
<max_swap_rate_explain>Artificially limits disk access using the specified I/O rate limit.[br]
Swap out requests that would cause the average I/O rate to exceed the limit are delayed.[br]
Individual swap in requests (i.e., HITs or READs) are not delayed, but they do contribute 
to measured swap rate and since they are placed in the same FIFO queue as swap out requests, 
they may wait longer if this value is smaller.[br]
This is necessary on file systems that buffer "too many" writes and then start blocking proxy and other processes while committing those writes to disk.[br]
Usually used together with SWAP Timeout to avoid excessive delays and queue overflows when disk demand exceeds available disk "bandwidth". [br]
By default and when set to zero, disables the disk I/O rate limit enforcement.
</max_swap_rate_explain>
<max_system_load>Maximale Systembelastung</max_system_load>

<max_system_load_squid_explain>By default, restart the proxy service if the system load exceed this value.[br]To disable this feature set it to 0 </max_system_load_squid_explain>

<memory_cache_mode>Memory cache mode</memory_cache_mode>
<memory_cache_mode_text>Controls which objects to keep in the memory cache:[br]
[b]always[/b]: Keep most recently fetched objects in memory (default)[br]
[b]disk[/b]: Only disk cache hits are kept in memory, which means an object must first be cached on disk and then hit a second time before cached in memory.[br]
[b]network[/b]: Only objects fetched from network is kept in memory.[br]
</memory_cache_mode_text>

<memory_pools>Memory Pools</memory_pools>
<memory_pools_explain>Wenn diese Option gesetzt ist, h%C3%A4lt der Proxy-Dienst Pools von zugewiesenem (aber ungenutztem) Speicher
Wenn der Speicher auf Ihrem System knapp ist und Sie glauben, dass Ihre malloc-Bibliothek
malloc-Bibliothek die Squid-Routinen %C3%BCbertrifft, deaktivieren Sie dies.</memory_pools_explain>
<memory_pools_limit>Memory pools limit</memory_pools_limit>
<memory_pools_limit_explain>
If set to a non-zero value, Proxy service will keep at most the specified
limit of allocated (but unused) memory in memory pools.
All free() requests that exceed this limit will be handled by your malloc library.
Proxy service does not pre-allocate any memory, just safe-keeps objects that otherwise would be free()d.[br]
Thus, it is safe to set memory pools limit to a reasonably high value even if your configuration will use less memory.[br]
If set to 0, Squid will keep all memory it can.[br]
That is, there 	will be no limit on the total amount of memory used for safe-keeping.[br]
An overhead for maintaining memory pools is not taken into account
when the limit is checked.[br]This overhead is close to four bytes per object kept.[br]
However, pools may actually _save_ memory because of reduced memory thrashing in your malloc library.
</memory_pools_limit_explain>
<memory_size_this_day>Speichergr%C3%B6%C3%9Fe heute</memory_size_this_day>
<memory_size_this_hour>Speichergr%C3%B6%C3%9Fe in dieser Stunde</memory_size_this_hour>
<memory_used>Verwendeter Speicher</memory_used>

</merge_access_logs_explain>

<microsoft_windows_softwares>Microsoft Windows Softwares</microsoft_windows_softwares>
<micro_hotspot_explain>The Micro HotSpot feature is a simple option claim to redirect Internet connections to an authentication page.[br]
It can be used if you need to authenticate users when using the Proxy in transparent mode or if you want an authentication without any popup box.[br]
The [b]Artica HotSpot[/b] main feature request to use 2 network interfaces and create a DMZ for the Hotspoted network.[br]This Micro Hotspot feature did not require such main changes and can be used in all proxy implementation in your Infrastructure.
</micro_hotspot_explain>

<milter_regex_explain>Milter-regex is a light daemon that is able to parse SMTP messages in order to discard, reject messages according regular expressions.[br]

Artica is able to update dedicated pattern from Artica cloud services in order to help you about fighting spam.

<min_packet_loss>MIN-Paketverlust</min_packet_loss>
<min_size>Minimal size</min_size>
<min_subqueue_msgs>Queue buffer</min_subqueue_msgs>
<min_subqueue_msgs_explain>The router put messages in a subqueue per each process set in this section.[br]
If this parameter is set to 0 the SMTP process will parse it's queue and send every mail stored in it's queue in realtime.[br]
If the router put only 1 message in subqueue, the SMTP process will create a remote connection to send this mail.[br]
To safe connections to the targeted server and send the desired X messages, the SMTP process must buffer enough messages in it's queue before trying to process.[br]
This parameter force each process to wait X messages stored in it's queue before processing messages. 
</min_subqueue_msgs_explain>
<min_subqueue_msgs_ttl>Buffered messages TTL</min_subqueue_msgs_ttl>
<min_subqueue_msgs_ttl_explain>This parameter force the SMTP instance to send messages that lives more than X seconds in a queue.[br]
For example, if the number of messages stored in the queue is less than the Queue buffer number, the SMTP process will wait maximum 30 seconds before force it to send them.
</min_subqueue_msgs_ttl_explain>
<min_successive_pkts_rcvd>MIN Successive packets received</min_successive_pkts_rcvd>
<min_ttl>Minimum Time to live</min_ttl>
<mirror>Mirror</mirror>
<MirrorDebianMaxExecTime_explain>Set here the maximal time to live for the executed process.[br]
It is usefull if you use the schedule to run the retreival process.[br]
For example start at 02h00 and maximal execute time for 240mn = 4 hours.[br]
0 means unlimited time</MirrorDebianMaxExecTime_explain>
<MirrorEnableDebianSchedule_explain>Is enabled, only scheduled task will be able to execute retreival.[br]See the schedule section</MirrorEnableDebianSchedule_explain>

<MYSQLNGINX_EXPLAIN>The MySQL Nginx storage service is designed to store statistics on your server.[br]
It is a dedicated service in order to not pollute other applications that require a MySQL service.[br]
With this service, you can display Web statistics of your reverse proxy or Web service.[br]
If you open this service, all Artica servers installed on your network can use this service in order to send statistics.
</MYSQLNGINX_EXPLAIN>
<MYSQLROUNDCUBE_EXPLAIN>
This wizard will help you to create a dedicated MySQL service for the RoundCube WebMail system.
The MySQL RoundCube storage service is designed to store settings and necessaries MySQL Tables on your server.[br]
It is a dedicated service in order to not pollute other applications that require a MySQL service.[br]
With this service, you can centralize RoundCube services on this server.[br]
</MYSQLROUNDCUBE_EXPLAIN>
<MYSQLROUNDCUBE_TYPE_EXPLAIN>[b]Client or Server ?[b][br]
Is this Artica server must use RoundCube settings stored on a remote Artica server (client) or 
is it a service that stores RoundCube service on this computer (server) ? 
</MYSQLROUNDCUBE_TYPE_EXPLAIN>
<MySQLStatisticsRetentionDays>Retention time in MySQL</MySQLStatisticsRetentionDays>
<MySQLStatisticsRetentionDays_explain>To provide real-time statistics and TOP graphs, Artica use the MySQL database.[br]
For the long term storage, and for generates reports, Artica use the InfluxDB database.[br]
Define here how many day you want data to be stored in MySQL database.[br]
If you have many data, you should reduce the retention time in order to safe performance
</MySQLStatisticsRetentionDays_explain>
<MySQLSyslogTypediff_explain>Currently the events logs are stored on a remote MySQL engine.[br]
In this case, the extract task must be performed on the remote server that store events
</MySQLSyslogTypediff_explain>
<MYSQLSYSLOG_EXPLAIN>The MySQL Syslog storage service is designed to store source logs on your server.[br]
It is a dedicated service in order to not pollute other applications that require a MySQL service.[br]
With this service, you can centralize system logs on this server.[br]
If you open this service, all Artica servers installed on your network can use this service in order to backup logs.
Backup logs is mandatory for the proxy according laws in your country.
</MYSQLSYSLOG_EXPLAIN>
<mysqlsyslog_finish>Your MySQL service is installed, you can change or tune this MySQL service
through the End-Users WebAccess interface by using an account with Linux system privileges.
Logs already stored on your main MySQL service will be transfered to this new service.
</mysqlsyslog_finish>
<MYSQLSYSLOG_TYPE_CLIENT_EXPLAIN>Define here credentials of the remote Artica server that will receive backuped logs</MYSQLSYSLOG_TYPE_CLIENT_EXPLAIN>
<MYSQLSYSLOG_TYPE_EXPLAIN>[b]Client or Server ?[b][br]
Is this Artica server must backup it's logs to a remote Artica server or is a service that stores backuped logs ?
</MYSQLSYSLOG_TYPE_EXPLAIN>
<MYSQLSYSLOG_TYPE_LOCAL_EXPLAIN>
This option will store old logs directly on this server.[br]
Please take car of the disk space of your storage directory.[br]
</MYSQLSYSLOG_TYPE_LOCAL_EXPLAIN>
<MYSQLSYSLOG_TYPE_NAS_EXPLAIN>The NAS system force your server to move directly old logs to a remote shared folder.[br]
Give here the parameters in order to allow your Artica server to store old events.[br]
[br][b]Note:[/b][br]
If you have selected MySQL server before, Artica will shutdown the MySQL service and you will not be able to retreive old files.[br]
In this case, use the export feature in order to purge the MySQL service.
</MYSQLSYSLOG_TYPE_NAS_EXPLAIN>
<MYSQLSYSLOG_TYPE_SERVER_EXPLAIN>Storing logs should take space, ensure that the specified directory have disk space.[br]
We suggest about 10/20Gb free space.[br]
If this server is [b]not[/b] designed to receive backuped logs from remote Artica servers, set 0 on Listen Port field.[br]
</MYSQLSYSLOG_TYPE_SERVER_EXPLAIN>
<MYSQLZARAFA_EXPLAIN>
This wizard will help you to create a dedicated MySQL service for Zarafa Mail server.
The MySQL Zarafa storage service is designed to store mailboxes on your server.[br]
It is a dedicated service in order to not pollute other applications that require a MySQL service.[br]
With this service, you can centralize Mailboxes service on this server.[br]
By using this service, you have to tranfert all Mailboxes stored on the main MySQL server to this new service. 
</MYSQLZARAFA_EXPLAIN>
<MYSQLZARAFA_TYPE_EXPLAIN>[b]Client or Server ?[b][br]

is it a service that stores mailboxes on this computer (server) ? 
</MYSQLZARAFA_TYPE_EXPLAIN>
<MYSQLZARAFA_TYPE_SERVER_EXPLAIN>Storing mailboxes should take space, ensure that the specified directory have disk space.[br]
We suggest about 100/500Gb free space.[br]

</MYSQLZARAFA_TYPE_SERVER_EXPLAIN>

<mysql_defrag_all_explain>This task is able to defrag the entire MySQL server by dump all datas, clean files and import datas in order to restart to a freshed MySQL indexes.
[br]You did not have to execute this task daily but sometimes during the Year...[br]
You have to schedule this task and disable it from the scheduler in order to just execute it manually 
</mysql_defrag_all_explain>
<mysql_engine>MySQL Engine</mysql_engine>
<mysql_events>MySQL events</mysql_events>
<mysql_explain_create_user>Define here the account privilege that will be able to be connected to the MySQL service.[br]
This form is for the whole MySQL service.[br]You will be able to define privileges on the database itself later.[br]
The {host} field specify the hostname (host1.example.com or *.example.com) or the IP address allowed to be connected whith this user.[br]
If you want to allow the member to be connected from any host, use the start character [b]*[/b] in the {host} field.[br]
You can use TCP/IP addresses/mask in the {host} field, examples:[br]
198.51.100.0/255.255.255.0[br]
192.168.1.1[br]
192.168.1.*[br]
</mysql_explain_create_user>

<mysql_hotspot_members_import_explain>Copy and paste members separated by a carriage return into this field, the format must be like this[br]
[b]username,password,validperiod[/b][br]
or separated by a space[br]
username password validperiod
If you did not set password then the importation task will assurme that the password will be the username.[br]
if maximal valid period (in minutes) is not set (or 0) then the importation task will use the unlimited time.[br]
Example:[br]
user1,P155wor1,2880[br]
user2[br]
user3,,3600[br]
</mysql_hotspot_members_import_explain>

<mysql_master>Mysql Master instance</mysql_master>
<mysql_multi_explain>This section is designed to manage several mysqld processes that listen for connections on different Unix socket files and TCP/IP ports.[br]
Each Mysql instance will be strictly separated it use it's own database.[br]
It use usefull if you want to be sure that no Websites or developpement application will damage the main mysql databases used by Artica.[br]
The number of Mysql instance depends of your server performance.[br]Please take carreful on that. Too many instances will reduce dramatically server performances.
</mysql_multi_explain>

<mysql_tables_maintenance>MySQL tables maintenance</mysql_tables_maintenance>
<mysql_tables_maintenance_explain>
Whenever you change the structure of a MySQL database, or remove a lot of data from it, the files can become fragmented resulting in a loss of performance, 
particularly when running queries.[br]
This task is able to defrag Mysql tables on your MySQL server
</mysql_tables_maintenance_explain>

<NetCoreRmemMax>Socket send/receive buffer</NetCoreRmemMax>
<NetCoreRmemMax_explain>This sets the max OS receive or Send buffer size for all types of connections</NetCoreRmemMax_explain>
<NetIpv4TcpMemLow_explain>Tells the kernel the low threshold.[br] Below this point,the TCP stack do not bother at all about putting any pressure on the memory usage by different TCP sockets</NetIpv4TcpMemLow_explain>
<NetIpv4TcpMemPages>Tells the kernel how many memory pages it may use maximally.[br]
If this value is reached, TCP streams and packets start getting [b]dropped[/b]
until we reach a lower memory usage again.[br] This value includes all TCP sockets currently in use</NetIpv4TcpMemPages>
<NetIpv4TcpMemPress>Tells the kernel at which point to start pressuring memory usage down</NetIpv4TcpMemPress>
<NetIpv4TcpRmemDef>Default receive buffer</NetIpv4TcpRmemDef>
<NetIpv4TcpRmemDef_explain>Tells the kernel the default receive buffer allocated for each TCP socket</NetIpv4TcpRmemDef_explain>
<NetIpv4TcpRmemMax>Maximum receive buffer</NetIpv4TcpRmemMax>
<NetIpv4TcpRmemMax_explain>Specifies the maximum receive buffer that can be allocated for a TCP socket</NetIpv4TcpRmemMax_explain>
<NetIpv4TcpRmemMin>Minimum Receive Buffer</NetIpv4TcpRmemMin>
<NetIpv4TcpRmemMin_explain>Tells the kernel the minimum receive buffer for each TCP connection,and this buffer is always allocated to a 
TCP socket, even under high pressure on the system</NetIpv4TcpRmemMin_explain>
<NetIpv4TcpWmemDef>Default buffer space</NetIpv4TcpWmemDef>
<NetIpv4TcpWmemDef_explain>The default buffer space allowed for a single TCP socket to use</NetIpv4TcpWmemDef_explain>
<NetIpv4TcpWmemMax>Maximum TCP send buffer</NetIpv4TcpWmemMax>
<NetIpv4TcpWmemMax_explain>Tells the kernel the maximum TCP send buffer space</NetIpv4TcpWmemMax_explain>
<NetIpv4TcpWmemMin>Minimum TCP Send buffer</NetIpv4TcpWmemMin>
<NetIpv4TcpWmemMin_explain>Tells the minimum TCP send buffer space available for a single TCP socket.</NetIpv4TcpWmemMin_explain>
<network2>Netzwerk</network2>
<NetworkAdvancedRouting_explain>If turned to OFF, you server run in single routing mode.[br]This means all routing information are stored in the main kernel central table.[br]
The advanced routing mode allows you to setup a routing table for each network interface.[br]
Each interface is hermetic and did not share its routing rules.
For example you can setup 2 network cards with the same network but using a different gateway....
</NetworkAdvancedRouting_explain>

<new_acls_rule_explain>Legen Sie den Regeltyp fest, den Sie anwenden m%C3%B6chten.
[b]Zugriff erlauben[/b]: Die Anfrage wird vom Proxy-Dienst zugelassen und umgeht Authentifizierungsmechanismen. URL-Filter und Virenschutz bleiben jedoch aktiv.[br]
[b]Zugriff verweigern[/b]: Die Anfrage wird sofort vom Proxy blockiert und kann nicht umgangen werden.[br]
Nach dem Erstellen dieser Regel k%C3%B6nnen Sie [b]Proxy-Objekte[/b] hinzuf%C3%BCgen, um festzulegen, wie die Regel auf Anfragen angewendet wird.[br]
Proxy-Objekte definieren die Kriterien f%C3%BCr die %C3%9Cbereinstimmung (z.â%80%AFB. IPs, Benutzer, Gruppen, Zeitpl%C3%A4ne usw.).</new_acls_rule_explain>
<new_acls_rule_header_explain>This rule allows you to play with HTTP headers sent by browsers (client) or reply by web servers (server).[br]
You must understand that the proxy is unable to modify any header in [b]HTTPs[/b] protocol.[br]
If you need to change headers in SSL protocol, you have to decrypt the SSL protocol using the MAN-IN-THE-MIDDLE method.
</new_acls_rule_header_explain>

<nginx_bulk_import_replace_explain>Add here replace rules you want to add in CSV format separated by a carriage return.[br]
replace pattern;Search pattern[br]
Example: [br]
newdomain.tld;mydomain.tld[br]
That will replace string mydomain.tld by newdomain.tld string.
</nginx_bulk_import_replace_explain>
<NGINX_DEFAULT_SERVER>If checked, this configuration will be defined as "default/catch-all", if request can be handle by other configuration, 
then this website will used as default</NGINX_DEFAULT_SERVER>
<nginx_default_server_explain>
If the Host header field does not match a server name, the Web server routes the request to the default server for the port on which the request arrived.[br]
The default server is the first one listed in the configuration, unless you enable this parameter
</nginx_default_server_explain>
<nginx_default_server_text>If green, this server will be used in priority mode.[br]
By default, the reverse proxy use the order setting to choose the best server.[br]
You can set several default servers.[br]
In this case the order will adjust which server will be used</nginx_default_server_text>
<nginx_destination>Where requests must be forwarded ?.[br]
You can define an IP Address (172.16.2.3);[br]
Or an hostname: www.mydomain.com[br]
Or an uri: http://www.mydomain.com
</nginx_destination>

<NGINX_FW_EXPLAIN>This feature allows you to log and/or block IP addresses sources from the FireWall when the reverse proxy sends a 403 error.[br]
A 403 error means "Access denied".
</NGINX_FW_EXPLAIN>
<nginx_import_explain>Mit dieser Funktion k%C3%B6nnen Sie eine Liste von Websites importieren, die in die Reverse-Proxy-Konfiguration aufgenommen werden sollen.
Kopieren Sie die Zeilen mit den Einstellungen und f%C3%BCgen Sie diese durch ein Komma getrennt ein:[br]
Quellserver,Seitenname,ssl-Modus (0/1 Standard=0),force domain.[br]
Beispiel:[br]
172.16.32.2,www.domain-front.tld,0,www.domain-back.tld[br]
172.16.32.3:9090,www.domain1.tld,0,www.domain1.tld[br]
www.domain3.tld,www.domaindest.tld,0,www.domaindest.tld[br]
[br]</nginx_import_explain>
<nginx_import_random_explain>Wenn Sie hier einen Wert eingeben, werden beim Import Webseiten mit einem zuf%C3%A4lligen Muster erstellt [br].
M%C3%B6gliche Werte sind: %a f%C3%BCr Alphatext oder %s f%C3%BCr numerischen Text.[br]
Zum Beispiel wird %a%s.domain.tld a1.domain.tld,b2.domain.tld,c3.domain.tld erzeugen.
Wenn Sie dem %s-Attribut 3-stellige Zahlen hinzuf%C3%BCgen m%C3%B6chten, setzen Sie %sx3 ( %a%sx3.domain.tld )</nginx_import_random_explain>
<nginx_inactive_explain>[b]Cache Invalidation[/b]provides the amount of time a cached request should remain 'valid'</nginx_inactive_explain>

Package must be a tar.gz file format.
</nginx_manual_update_text>
<NGINX_MAXACCESS_FW_EXPLAIN>If this value is up to 0, then the source IP address will be blocked by the firewall after exceed this number [b]by hour[/b].</NGINX_MAXACCESS_FW_EXPLAIN>

<nginx_path_explain>Paths are requests inside the domain.[br]
it can be a folder ( /myfolder/ ) or a requests file ( /myimage.png ) [br]or a regular expression ( ~* ^.+.(jpg|jpeg|gif|css|png|js|ico|html|xml|txt)$
these requests can be forwarded to a local directory or forwared to a remote server.
</nginx_path_explain>
<NGINX_PRIVS_EXPLAIN>This section allows members to manage this website.</NGINX_PRIVS_EXPLAIN>
<nginx_proxy_cookie_domain>Replace in the domain attribute of the "Set-Cookie" header fields of the proxied server response.[br]
Suppose the proxied server returned the "Set-Cookie" header field with the attribute "domain=localhost" and replace it with the connection domain.
</nginx_proxy_cookie_domain>
<nginx_proxy_read_timeout>Diese Direktive legt das Lese-Timeout f%C3%BCr die Antwort des Proxy-Servers fest[br].
Sie legt fest, wie lange der Reverse-Proxy wartet, um die Antwort auf eine Anfrage zu erhalten.[br]
Die Zeit%C3%BCberschreitung wird nicht f%C3%BCr die gesamte Antwort festgelegt, sondern nur zwischen zwei Lesevorg%C3%A4ngen.</nginx_proxy_read_timeout>
<nginx_replace_explain>Replace rules allows you to force the reverse proxy to replace web pages on-the-fly</nginx_replace_explain>

<nginx_service_explain>A service is an HTTP/HTTPs service that able to provide Web application.[br]This service can handle multiple hostname of domain name.[br]
After creating this service, you will be able to define which domain this service will be able to populate.</nginx_service_explain>
<nginx_stream_explain>[b]Create a port forwarder[/b][br]
A port forwarder is similar to a NAT Firewall behavior with logging feature.</nginx_stream_explain>
<nginx_subst_explain>This rule can do both regular expression and fixed string substitutions on response bodies.[br]
Here some examples[br]
st(\d*).example.com replaced by $1.example.com with ir flags[br]
a.example.com replaced by s.example.com with g flags[br] 
flags can be:[br]
[b]g[/b]: Replace all the match strings.[br]
[b]i[/b]: Perform a case-insensitive match.[br]
[b]o[/b]: Just replace the first one.[br]
[b]r[/b]: The pattern is treated as a regular expression, default is fixed string. [br]
</nginx_subst_explain>
<NGINX_USE_SSL_EXPLAIN>If set then the SSL will be generated for the defined port.[br]
There is a tips in order to define this Web server on HTTP and HTTPS port.[br]
If you enable this option and you set 80 as port, then this web server will listen in both 80/443 ports in order to provide HTTPS/HTTP service
</NGINX_USE_SSL_EXPLAIN>
<NGINX_USE_SSL_EXPLAIN2>Turn SSL will only turn SSL on the reverse proxy.[br]By default, the reverse proxy is able to communicate with the backend Web server in HTTP mode.[br]
If the backend server is SSL too, turn to green this feature.
</NGINX_USE_SSL_EXPLAIN2>

<nginx_welcome_step1>Welcome to the reverse proxy server creation wizard.[br]
This wizard will help you to protect your Web site trough this machine.[br]
First define the web site name.[br]This server will be in charge to receive connections from your users.[br]It will replace your orginal Web server.[br]
Set here your server like http://www.mywebsite.com if you use HTTP or http[b]s[/b]://www.mywebsite.com if you want reverse proxy service to generate the HTTPS.
</nginx_welcome_step1>
<nginx_welcome_step2>Define here your real destination Web server.[br]you can set the distnation in several ways:[br]
[b]http://10.2.3.4:80[/b] Connections from %s will be redirected to the HTTP server 10.2.3.4 port 80[br]
[b]https://10.2.3.4[/b] Connections from %s will be redirected to the HTTP[b]S[/b] server 10.2.3.4 port 443[br]
[b]https://10.2.3.4:9000[/b] Connections from %s will be redirected to the HTTP[b]S[/b server 10.2.3.4 port 9000[br]
[b]http://10.2.3.4:443/blog1[/b] Connections from %s will be redirected to the HTTP server 10.2.3.4 port 80 and path blog1 direcly.
[b]http://www.domain.com[/b]  Connections from %s will be redirected to the HTTP 10.2.3.4 and will force host www.domain.com to access to virtual host[br]
</nginx_welcome_step2>
<nginx_welcome_step3>[b]Your settings[/b][br]
Wen users will have access to this server with requests for [b]%s[/b], the reverse proxy will redirect requests to [b]%d[/b].[br]
If you are aggree to these setttings, press on the build button to create the configuration.[br]
After complete, you can return to the configuration in order to tune your reverse proxy settings and create more options.
</nginx_welcome_step3>
<nginx_zavailb_explain>Your website is not applied to the reverse proxy service, compile it to make it available</nginx_zavailb_explain>
<ngx_bandwidth_explain>
You can configure the maximum download or upload speed for TCP connections.[br]
With these settings a client can download data through a single connection at a maximum 
speed of xx kilobytes per second, and upload data through a single connection at 
a maximum speed of yy kilobytes per second.[br]
However, the client can open several connections.[br]
So if the goal is to limit overall speed of loading for each client, 
the number of connections must also be limited to 1 in {limit_connections_ip} field.
</ngx_bandwidth_explain>
<ngx_stream_access_module>This feature allows limiting access to certain client addresses.[br]
The rules are checked in sequence until the first match is found.[br]
You can add addresses using the folowing format: 192.168.1.1, 10.1.1.0/16 and special token "*" for all addresses.
</ngx_stream_access_module>

<opcache_explain>Normallement les scripts PHP sont compilés à la volée.[br]Une partie de la ressource machine est de convertir le code en un code exécutable.[br]
OPcache permet d'effectuer cette compilation une seule fois via la mise en cache des conversions.[br]
Le script peut être alors chargé directement depuis le cache aussi rapidement que désiré.[br]Dans bien des cas, ceci assure une amélioration notable des performances.</opcache_explain>

<OpenVPNBlockLocal>Block access to local LAN</OpenVPNBlockLocal>
<OpenVPNBlockLocal_explain>Wenn aktiviert, wird der Zugriff auf das lokale LAN blockiert, wenn der Tunnel aktiv ist, mit Ausnahme des LAN-Gateways selbst.[br]
Dies wird erreicht, indem das lokale LAN (mit Ausnahme der LAN-Gateway-Adresse) in den Tunnel geleitet wird.</OpenVPNBlockLocal_explain>
<OpenVPNClientCertNotRequired>Client certificate is not required</OpenVPNClientCertNotRequired>
<OpenVPNClientCertNotRequired_explain>Don't require client certificate, 
client will authenticate using username/password only.[br]
Be aware that using this directive is less secure than requiring certificates from all clients.[br]
If you use this directive, the entire responsibility of authentication will rest on your authentication method.[br]
If you don't use this option, but you also specify an authentication method, then VPN server will perform double authentication.[br]
The client certificate verification AND the authentication method defined.</OpenVPNClientCertNotRequired_explain>
<OpenVPNClientTOClient>Clients access to other clients</OpenVPNClientTOClient>
<OpenVPNClientTOClient_explain>Because the VPN server mode handles multiple clients through a single interface, it is effectively a router.[br]
This feature tells VPN service to internally route client-to-client traffic rather than pushing all client-originating traffic to the interface.[br]
When this option is used, each client will "see" the other clients which are currently connected.[br]
Otherwise, each client will only see the server.[br]
[b]Don't use this option if you want to firewall tunnel traffic using custom, per-client rules.[/b]</OpenVPNClientTOClient_explain>
<OpenVPNPing>Ping</OpenVPNPing>
<OpenVPNPingRestart>Ping restart</OpenVPNPingRestart>
<OpenVPNPingRestart_explain>Trigger a SIGUSR1 restart after n seconds pass without reception of a ping or other packet from remote.[br]
This option is useful in cases where the remote peer has a dynamic IP address and a low-TTL DNS name is used to track the IP address using a service such as http://dyndns.org/ + a dynamic DNS client such as ddclient.[br]
If the peer cannot be reached, a restart will be triggered, causing the hostname of the server to be re-resolved (if resolv retry is also specified).[br]
In server mode, will always be applied to individual client instance objects, never to whole server itself.[br]
Note also in server mode that any internally generated signal which would normally cause a restart, will cause the deletion of the client instance object instead.
In client mode, the -parameter is set to 120 seconds by default. [br]
This default will hold until the client pulls a replacement value from the server, based on the setting in the server configuration.[br]
To disable the 120 second default, set it to 0 on the client.</OpenVPNPingRestart_explain>
<OpenVPNPing_explain>Ping remote over the TCP/UDP control channel if no packets have been sent for at least n seconds.</OpenVPNPing_explain>
<OpenVPNRedirectGateway>Handle all traffic</OpenVPNRedirectGateway>
<OpenVPNRedirectGateway_explain>If turned to ON, All traffic will be redirected trough the VPN connection.[br]
You need to specify on which interface you want VPN to forward traffic.[br]
For example, if you want Internet access going to the VPN connection.
</OpenVPNRedirectGateway_explain>
<OpenVPNTCPLIMIT>Maximum number of queued TCP output packets</OpenVPNTCPLIMIT>
<OpenVPNTCPLIMIT_EXPLAIN>When OpenVPN is tunneling data from a device to a remote client over a TCP connection, it is possible that the TUN/TAP device might produce data at a faster rate than the TCP connection can support. When the number of queued TCP output packets reaches this limit for a given client connection, 
OpenVPN will start to drop outgoing packets directed at this client.</OpenVPNTCPLIMIT_EXPLAIN>
<openvpn_authgroups_explain>Geben Sie hier die Liste der Gruppen an, denen die Nutzung des VPN-Dienstes erlaubt sein soll.[br]
Sie m%C3%BCssen nur die Gruppennamen angeben, getrennt durch einen Zeilenumbruch.[br]
Wenn keine Gruppe festgelegt ist, kann jeder den VPN-Dienst nutzen.[br]
F%C3%BCr LDAP und Active Directory ist der Standardport 389. Wenn Sie einen anderen Port verwenden m%C3%BCssen, setzen Sie den Hostnamen auf Adresse:Port.</openvpn_authgroups_explain>
<openvpn_fragment_explain>
Enable internal datagram fragmentation so that no UDP datagrams are sent which are larger than max bytes.[br]
The max parameter is interpreted in the same way as the Maximum Transmission Units, i.e. the UDP packet size after encapsulation 
overhead has been added in, but not including the UDP header itself.[br]
Thisoption option only makes sense when you are using the UDP protocol.[br]
It adds 4 bytes of overhead per datagram.
It should also be noted that this option is not meant to replace UDP fragmentation at the IP stack level.[br]
It is only meant as a last resort when path MTU discovery is broken.[br]
Using this option is less efficient than fixing path MTU discovery for your IP link and using native IP fragmentation instead.[br]
Having said that, there are circumstances where using OpenVPN's internal fragmentation capability may be your only option, 
such as tunneling a UDP multicast stream which requires fragmentation.
Setting to 0 disable the option
</openvpn_fragment_explain>
<openvpn_handle_all_traffic_not_interface>VPN sessions was configured to redirect all traffic to the VPN tunnel but you did not have defined where to redirect traffic on the server.[br]
This means you have to define it on each client script to allow VPN users to use your internal and external resources.</openvpn_handle_all_traffic_not_interface>
<openvpn_mssfix_explain>Announce to TCP sessions running over the tunnel that they should limit their send packet sizes such that after VPN server
has encapsulated them, the resulting UDP packet size that VPN server sends to its peer will not exceed max bytes.[br]
The max parameter is interpreted in the same way as the Maximum Transmission Units parameter, i.e. the UDP packet size after encapsulation 
overhead has been added in, but not including the UDP header itself.[br]
Set to 0 disable the option
</openvpn_mssfix_explain>
<openvpn_new_interface_explain>In order to manage the VPN service, you have to enter into the dedicated Web Console.[br]
Artica offer capabilities to create a VPN administrator that is able to only in charge of monitor and manage VPN connections.</openvpn_new_interface_explain>
<OPENVPN_NOT_INSTALLED>OpenVPN Service is not installed</OPENVPN_NOT_INSTALLED>

In this case you will be able to link Artica servers with a VPN network and/or allow clients to be connected to your LAN using a dedicated VPN client.[br]
Your Firewall needs to only to redirect defined Open VPN service port (UDP or TCP) from Internet to this server.
</openvpn_whatis>

</openvpn_wizard_1>

<override-expire>overrides or ignores the [b]Expires[/b] header, 
which is the main player for determining the expiry time of a cached response.[br]
As the Expires header is ignored, the values of the minimal, maximal, and percentage parameters 
will play an essential role in determining the freshness of a response.
</override-expire>
<override-lastmod>
Force proxy to ignore the [b]Last-Modified[/b] header, 
which will eventually enforce the use of minimal value to determine the freshness of an object.[br]
This option is of no use, if you have set the minimal value to zero.
</override-lastmod>

<paranoid_mode>Paranoid mode</paranoid_mode>
<paranoid_squid_mode_explain>The paranoid mode is designed to reduce Web error page load by a flooder clients.[br]
If a computer is infected by a Malware that want to access to Internet of if the client use an application denied by a policy, all requests will use process on the proxy ( requests processing, web page error generation.).[br]
This mode is able to deny the workstation access to Internet or deny access to the targeted web site trough a single web page.
</paranoid_squid_mode_explain>

Default is auto to automatically determine the status of the peer</parent_options_connection_auth>
<parent_options_connect_fail_limit>Specifies how many times connecting to a backend must fail before it is marked as down. Default is 10.</parent_options_connect_fail_limit>
<parent_options_connect_timeout>This parameter specifies how long to wait (seconds) for a pending TCP connection to a parent.[br]
The default is 30 seconds.</parent_options_connect_timeout>
<parent_options_login_pass>Vom Client empfangene Anmeldedaten an diesen Server senden.
Eine Authentifizierung ist bei dieser Option nicht erforderlich.[br]
Wenn es keine vom Client bereitgestellten Authentifizierungs-Header gibt, die weitergegeben werden m%C3%BCssen, aber Benutzername und Passwort von einem externen ACL user= und password= Ergebnis-Tag verf%C3%BCgbar sind,[br]
k%C3%B6nnen sie stattdessen gesendet werden.[br]
[i]Hinweis: Um dies mit proxy_auth zu kombinieren, m%C3%BCssen beide Proxys dieselbe Benutzerdatenbank nutzen, da HTTP nur eine einzige Anmeldung zul%C3%A4sst (eine f%C3%BCr den Proxy, eine f%C3%BCr den Ursprungsserver).[br]Seien Sie au%C3%9Ferdem gewarnt, dass dies das Proxy-Passwort Ihres Benutzers f%C3%BCr die Gegenstelle offenlegt. VERWENDEN SIE ES MIT VORSICHT.[/i]</parent_options_login_pass>
<parent_options_login_passthru>Senden Sie die vom Client empfangenen Anmeldedaten an diesen Server.
Sowohl Proxy- als auch WWW-Authorization-Header werden unver%C3%A4ndert an den Server weitergegeben.
Eine Authentifizierung ist f%C3%BCr diesen Proxy nicht erforderlich, damit er funktioniert.
[i]Hinweis: Es wird jede Form der Authentifizierung durchgelassen, aber nur Basic auth funktioniert %C3%BCber einen Proxy, es sei denn, die connection-auth-Optionen werden ebenfalls verwendet.[/i]</parent_options_login_passthru>

<parse_squid_framework>Check framework orders queue</parse_squid_framework>
<parse_squid_framework_explain>Artica monitor Proxy and web filter service process in realtime.[br]For performances purpose it is not intended to the monitor to perform operations when detecting troubles.[br]
The monitor save orders to a MySQL table in order to process them later.[br]
This task is able to parse orders in the MySQL table and execute specified processes.</parse_squid_framework_explain>
<parse_squid_logs_queue>Parse queue requests</parse_squid_logs_queue>
<parse_squid_logs_queue_explain>Artica monitor proxy requests in realtime but it not insert them into MySQL database in realtime for performances purpose.[br]
The realtime monitor save each request in a single file stored in a directory.[br]
This background task is able to parse all files in queue directory, analyze them and save data into MySQL database.[br]
We suggest to not define a schedule more than 10 minutes to prevent too many files in the queue directory.
</parse_squid_logs_queue_explain>

this is the reason that the web service listen on 80 and 443 ( mandatory ).[br]

<persistent_connections>Persistent connections</persistent_connections>
<persistent_connections_explain>
HTTP persistent connection, also called HTTP keep-alive, or HTTP connection reuse, 
is the idea of using a single TCP connection to send and receive multiple HTTP requests/responses, 
as opposed to opening a new connection for every single request/response pair.[br]
If HTTP persistent connections are enabled, it will force the proxy to keep open connections at increase CPU consumption.[br]
By default, HTTP persistent connections are disabled.
</persistent_connections_explain>
<persistent_request_timeout>Zeit%C3%BCberschreitung bei anhaltenden Anfragen</persistent_request_timeout>
<persistent_request_timeout_text>This defines the time period to wait for the next HTTP request on a persistent connection after the previous request
completes</persistent_request_timeout_text>

<postfix_automation_about>Artica White and Blacklist Automation is a process that able to parse 
your mailboxes automatically ( according defined schedules ).[br]
It is designed to read the Junk E-Mail mailbox and add all senders to the user's blacklist database and purge the mailbox.[br]
It parse the Sent Items too in order to put all recipients to the user's whitelist database.[br]
[b]Whith this process, you just have to explain to users to put non-wanted emails to the Junk mailbox.[/b][br]
</postfix_automation_about>

<postfix_ip_reputation_explain>IP reputation allows you to link your SMTP service to a DNS black database.[br]
When SMTP servers are connected to your service, it checks the IP address on these services.[br]
If the IP address is listed, then the connection is [b]rejected[/b] and the SMTP server is not able to send messages.
</postfix_ip_reputation_explain>
<postfix_mailbox_transport_art_expl>Dieser Abschnitt zwingt das Postfix-Mailsystem, Nachrichten an den endg%C3%BCltigen Mailboxdienst zu liefern.
Standardm%C3%A4%C3%9Fig verwendet Artica den auf Ihrem System installierten lokalen MDA (Zarafa Mail Server oder Cyrus-imapd).
Er wird normalerweise verwendet, wenn kein MDA-Dienst auf dem System installiert ist oder wenn Sie die endg%C3%BCltigen Ziele an Ihren Remote-Dienst weiterleiten m%C3%B6chten.
Wenn Sie hier einen Eintrag setzen, wird Artica diesen verwenden, anstatt zu versuchen, den richtigen zu finden.[br]
Definieren Sie einen LMTP-Befehl oder einen Dienst, der verwendet werden soll, z. B:
[br]Lokaler Cyrus-imapd-Dienst: &quot;cyrus&quot;[br]
Entfernter LMTP-Dienst: lmtp:10.10.10.1:2000[br]
Lokaler LMTP-Socket: lmtp:unix:/path/to/lmtp.sock[br]</postfix_mailbox_transport_art_expl>

<PostgreSQLEffectiveCacheSize> This value tells PostgreSQL's optimizer how much memory PostgreSQL has available 
for caching data and helps in determing whether or not it use an index or not.[br]
The larger the value increases the likely hood of using an index.[br]
This should be set to the amount of memory allocated to shared_buffers plus the amount of OS cache available.[br]
Often this is more than 50% of the total system memory.
</PostgreSQLEffectiveCacheSize>
<PostgreSQLSharedBuffer>Editing this option is the simplest way to improve the performance of 
your database server.[br]The default is pretty low for most modern hardware.[br]
General wisdom says that this should be set to roughly 25% of available RAM on the system.[br]
Like most of the options I will outline here you will simply need to try them at different levels 
(both up and down ) and see how well it works on your particular system.[br]
Most people find that setting it larger than a third starts to degrade performance.</PostgreSQLSharedBuffer>
<PostgreSQLWorkMem> This option is used to control the amount of memory using in sort operations and hash tables.[br]
While you may need to increase the amount of memory if you do a ton of sorting in your application, care needs to be taken.[br]
This isn't a system wide parameter, but a per operation one.[br]
So if a complex query has several sort operations in it it will use multiple work_mem units of memory.[br]
Not to mention that multiple backends could be doing this at once.[br]
This query can often lead your database server to swap if the value is too large.
</PostgreSQLWorkMem>
<PostgreSQL_explain>Die PostgreSQL-Datenbank ist f%C3%BCr die Speicherung von Ereignissen und Statistiken f%C3%BCr eine mittlere Laufzeit zust%C3%A4ndig.</PostgreSQL_explain>

<PowerDNS-allow-from>Netzmasken (sowohl IPv4 als auch IPv6), die den Server nutzen d%C3%BCrfen.[br]
Die Standardeinstellung erlaubt nur den Zugriff von privaten IP-Adressen nach RFC 1918.[br]
Aufgrund der aggressiven Natur des Internets heutzutage ist es sehr empfehlenswert
wird dringend empfohlen, den Rekursor nicht f%C3%BCr das gesamte Internet zu %C3%B6ffnen.[br]
Fragen von IP-Adressen, die hier nicht aufgef%C3%BChrt sind, werden ignoriert und erhalten keine Antwort.</PowerDNS-allow-from>
<PowerDNS-allow-from-default>Die Standardeinstellung erlaubt nur den Zugriff von privaten IP-Adressen nach RFC 1918: [b]192.168.0.0/16, 10.0.0.0/16, 127.0.0.0/8, 172.16.0.0/12[/b]</PowerDNS-allow-from-default>
<PowerDNSMaxCacheEntries>Maximum number of entries in the query cache.[br]
1 million (the default) will generally suffice for most installations</PowerDNSMaxCacheEntries>
<PowerDNSMaxPacketCacheEntries>Maximum number of entries in the packet cache.[br]
1 million (the default) will generally suffice for most installations</PowerDNSMaxPacketCacheEntries>

<privkey>Private key</privkey>
<privkey_ssl_explain>A private key is created during asymmetric-key encryption, 
as part of [b]public key cryptography[/b].[br]
The private key is used to decrypt content and transform it to a readable form.[br]
The private key is a matching, but different, key to the public one.[br]
Public and private keys are paired for secure communication.
</privkey_ssl_explain>

<proxy_auth_ads_explain>Definieren Sie eine Active-Directory-Gruppe, es wird wahr sein, wenn das verbundene Mitglied ein Mitglied der definierten Active-Directory-Gruppe ist.[br]
Dieses Objekt ist dynamisch, d.h. der Proxy %C3%BCberpr%C3%BCft die Mitglieder der definierten Gruppe bei jeder Browsersitzung.</proxy_auth_ads_explain>
<proxy_auth_statad_explain>Check a member against an Active Directory group stored on disk.[br]
This object save all members on disk when compiling rules.[br]
This group have better performances because the proxy did not have to query Active Directory each time the session is created</proxy_auth_statad_explain>
<proxy_behavior>Proxy behavior</proxy_behavior>
<proxy_behavior_explain>You can define here the behavior of your proxy service.[br]
You have 3 ways to define how your proxy can serve Internet.[br]
[b]Exclusive Reverse Proxy:[/b][br]
The Proxy service act only in the reverse mode, no open port is allowed in order to surf trough Internet.[br]
It is designed to protect your local Web servers.[br]
[b]Exclusive Internet Proxy:[/b][br]
The Proxy service act only as a standard proxy in order to accelerate Internet browsing.[br]
[b]Mixed Mode[/b][br]
The mixed mode allows your proxy service act as a proxy server and a reverse proxy server.[br]
We did not recommand this mode.
</proxy_behavior_explain>
<proxy_buffering>Proxy buffering</proxy_buffering>
<proxy_buffering_text>
activate response buffering of the proxied server.[br]
If buffering is activated, then reverse-porxy reads the answer from the proxied server as fast as possible,
saving it in the buffer as configured by directives proxy buffer size and proxy buffers.[br]
If the response does not fit into memory, then parts of it will be written to disk.[br]
If buffering is switched off, then the response is synchronously transferred to client immediately as it is received.
[br]Reverse-proxy does not attempt to read the entire answer from the proxied server, 
the maximum size of data which nginx can accept from the server is set by directive proxy buffer size. 
</proxy_buffering_text>
<proxy_buffers>Proxy-Puffer</proxy_buffers>
<proxy_buffers_text>Diese Direktive legt die Anzahl und Gr%C3%B6%C3%9Fe der Puffer fest,in die die vom Proxy-Server erhaltene Antwort eingelesen werden soll.[br]
Standardm%C3%A4%C3%9Fig ist die Gr%C3%B6%C3%9Fe eines Puffers gleich der Gr%C3%B6%C3%9Fe der Seite in k</proxy_buffers_text>
<proxy_buffer_size>Proxy Puffergr%C3%B6%C3%9Fe</proxy_buffer_size>
<proxy_buffer_size_text>Legt die Menge an Speicher fest, die der Reverse-Proxy f%C3%BCr jede Anfrage an den Proxy-Server zuweist[br].
Dieser kleine Teil des Speichers wird f%C3%BCr das Lesen und Speichern des winzigen Teils der Antwort - der HTTP-Header - verwendet.
Die HTTP-Header entsprechen in der Regel einem sehr kleinen Teil der vollst%C3%A4ndigen Nutzdaten der Anfrage oder Antwort.
[br][b]Es macht keinen Sinn, bis zu 128 Kilobyte f%C3%BCr den Puffer der HTTP-Antwort-Header zu reservieren.[/b]</proxy_buffer_size_text>
<PROXY_CACHE_FEATURE>Caching objects on local disk</PROXY_CACHE_FEATURE>
<PROXY_CACHE_FEATURE_EXPLAIN>Aktivieren Sie die M%C3%B6glichkeit, heruntergeladene Objekte auf lokalen Laufwerken zu speichern, um Bandbreite zu sparen und ein solides Cache-System bereitzustellen.</PROXY_CACHE_FEATURE_EXPLAIN>
<proxy_cache_min_uses>Minimale zwischengespeicherte Anfragen</proxy_cache_min_uses>
<proxy_cache_min_uses_text>Anzahl der Anfragen, nach denen die Antwort im Cache gespeichert wird[br].
Diese Option ist n%C3%BCtzlich, wenn sich der Cache st%C3%A4ndig f%C3%BCllt, da sie daf%C3%BCr sorgt, dass nur die am h%C3%A4ufigsten aufgerufenen Elemente in den Cache aufgenommen werden.</proxy_cache_min_uses_text>
<PROXY_CACHE_STORED_OBJECTS_EXPLAIN>Mit dieser Funktion k%C3%B6nnen Sie zwischengespeicherte Objekte im Speicher oder auf den Festplatten auflisten.
Es handelt sich nicht um eine Echtzeitfunktion, da das Extrahieren von zwischengespeicherten Objekten Hardware-Leistung verbraucht[br].
Sie m%C3%BCssen die Analyseaufgabe ausf%C3%BChren, um die Objekte anzuzeigen.</PROXY_CACHE_STORED_OBJECTS_EXPLAIN>
<proxy_cache_valid>Cache-Zeit</proxy_cache_valid>
<proxy_cache_valid_text>Definieren Sie, wie lange (in Minuten) die Anfrage zwischengespeichert werden soll</proxy_cache_valid_text>

%C3%9Cberpr%C3%BCfen Sie die Watchdog-Ereignisse, um zu sehen, warum der Notfallmodus aktiviert wurde.

<proxy_max_temp_file_size>Max temporary file size</proxy_max_temp_file_size>
<proxy_max_temp_file_size_text>
When buffering of responses from the proxied server is enabled, and the whole response does not fit into the buffers set by the proxy buffer size and proxy buffers directives, 
a part of the response can be saved to a temporary file.[br]
This directive sets the maximum size of the temporary file.[br]
The size of data written to the temporary file at a time is set by the proxy temp_file_write_size directive.</proxy_max_temp_file_size_text>

<proxy_temp_file_write_size>Temporay file limit</proxy_temp_file_write_size>
<proxy_temp_file_write_size_text>
Limits the size of data written to a temporary file at a time, when buffering of responses from the proxied server to temporary files is enabled.[br]
By default, size is limited by two buffers set by the proxy buffer size and proxy buffers directives.[br]
The maximum size of a temporary file is set by the Max temporary file size directive. 
</proxy_temp_file_write_size_text>

<purge_statistics_database>Bereinigung alter Statistikdaten</purge_statistics_database>
<purge_statistics_database_explain>Purge and backup statistics table from MySQL database</purge_statistics_database_explain>
<purge_statistics_database_explain2>This section allows you to define the data retention and purge process[br]For MySQL Proxy statistics database generated by Artica.[br]
The process export MySQL data to a compressed file and remove old tables from the MySQL engine.[br]
You will be able to restore backup container later.[br]
[b]Note about the retention parameter:[/b][br]
Artica build about 3/5 tables per day.Each table represents 2 files on your disk.[br]For example 90 days = (90x5)x2 = 900 files.[br]
More you have tables, more your server performances will be impacted. 
</purge_statistics_database_explain2>

<ready_to_build>Ready to build settings</ready_to_build>
<read_ahead_gap>Read AHEAD Gap</read_ahead_gap>
<read_ahead_gap_text>
The amount of data the cache will buffer ahead of what has been sent to the client 
when retrieving an object from another server.[br]
It limits the amount of memory used for in-transit data, and limits long
running connections to the speed of the client.[br]
Lets imagine an user requests a 1GB file.[br] If your value is
1000M then the proxy service will read all the file at full network speed, buffering
it in memory.[br]The end result is that you runs out of both memory and
internet bandwidth. 
</read_ahead_gap_text>
<read_timeout>Lesen Zeit%C3%BCberschreitung</read_timeout>
<read_timeout_text>Bei jeder erfolgreichen read()-Anforderung wird die Zeit%C3%BCberschreitung auf diesen Wert zur%C3%BCckgesetzt[br]Wenn innerhalb dieser Zeitspanne keine Daten gelesen werden, wird die Anforderung abgebrochen und mit ERR_READ_TIMEOUT protokolliert</read_timeout_text>

<redirect_uri>Umleitung</redirect_uri>
<redirect_uri_explain>Add in this form the desired redirected URL, the can be a path ( /some/where ) or a full url like
http://my.new-redirection.com/authenticate.php<br>
Artica is able to replace some tokens in your uri.[br]
available tokens should be %LANG%, %SHLVL%, %LANGUAGE%, %QUERY_STRING%, %REQUEST_METHOD%, %CONTENT_TYPE%, %CONTENT_LENGTH%, %SCRIPT_FILENAME%, %SCRIPT_NAME%, %PATH_INFO%, %REQUEST_URI%, %DOCUMENT_URI%, %SERVER_PROTOCOL%, %GATEWAY_INTERFACE%, %HTTP_HOST%, %HTTP_X_FORWARDED_FOR%, %HTTP_X_REAL_IP%, %HTTP_USER_AGENT%, %HTTP_ACCEPT%, %HTTP_ACCEPT_LANGUAGE%, %HTTP_ACCEPT_ENCODING%
[br]
You can add a dynamic token that corespond to a GET method or COOKIE token.[br]
You need to use %_GET_KEY% as KEY is the request sent by the browser.[br]
The same with cookies by using %_COOKIE_KEY%.[br]
For example.[br]
http://some/logon.php?query=%QUERY_STRING%&lang=%LANGUAGE%&result=%_GET_session%&session-id=%_COOKIE_JSESSIONID%
</redirect_uri_explain>
<redirect_uri_text>Redirect your request</redirect_uri_text>

Dies kann die Latenzzeit erh%C3%B6hen, aber die Clients erhalten immer die neuesten Daten.</refresh-ims>

<reload_into_ims>Reload redirected to cache</reload_into_ims>
<reload_into_ims_explain>
When turn to green this option, client no-cache or "reload" requests will be changed to If-Modified-Since requests.[br]
Doing this VIOLATES the HTTP standard.[br]
Turning it green may give proxy a better hit ratio, but it will no longer be
possible for the end users to use shift+reload to force the download of
a fresh copy.
</reload_into_ims_explain>
<reload_in_public_mode>Reload Proxy services in public mode</reload_in_public_mode>
